fields.description:
When you're deleting a Remote Branch it's a destructive operation should have a more clearer message as SourceTree will actually push the deletion to the remote automatically.
Currently the message is exactly the same as when deleting a local branch but the consequences are a bit more dangerous.
It would be good that it displayed something like:

{code}
Confirm Remote Branch Deletion

Are you sure you want to delete the following remote branch? 
(The removal will be automatically pushed to the remote repository)

[remote-name]/[branch-name]
{code}
fields.summary: Improve message on deletion of branches from Remotes

fields.description: It would be nice if SourceTree would show a pull/push badge with the number of incoming or outgoing commits in the Dock icon.
fields.summary: Show pull/push badges in Dock Icon

fields.description:
Add support for git notes: http://schacon.github.com/git/git-notes.html

Requested here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/38917/please-support-git-notes
fields.summary: Git notes support

fields.description: Allow a feature on SourceTree where one can push to multiple remotes at the same time.
fields.summary: Push To Multiple Remotes At Once

fields.description: This will allow easily find project in Finder.
fields.summary: Add 'Show In Finder' action for bookmarked repositories in 'Bookmarks' screen.

fields.description: See https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/38790/hg-shelve-option-git-not-recognized
fields.summary: User-installed hgshelve extension overriding embedded hgattic?

fields.description:
A convenience improvement would be to cope silently with the case where a suer pastes a complete command such as 'git clone https://..' into the clone URL text box, and to strip off the leading text, since it's quite easy to copy a full command from instructions or websites.

Requested by Mike on HipChat.
fields.summary: Intercept paste on clone URL field and strip out 'git clone' / 'hg clone' prefixes

fields.description: Allow users to see SourceForge projects in SourceTree as well (SourceForge integration).
fields.summary: SourceForge Integration

fields.description: Allow users to open a nice large graph of the commits and branches. Although there already is a graph that shows this on SourceTree, it would be nice to see a large fullscreen horizontal one, as well as the location of all of the branches and repos (similar to the network graph visualizer on GitHub).
fields.summary: Large Network Graph Visualizer

fields.description:
Customer Request:
{quote}All the icons in the toolbars look somewhat out of place on a Mac (unlike the application icon, which is fine), but the yellow folders in particular stand out. Could you make them look like the folders in the Finder?
http://i.imgur.com/TIEmn.png

Mac folder icons have been (varying shades of) light blue since 1991. Windows folder icons have been yellow since 1995. Hence, those yellow folders say "Windows" to me.
{quote}
fields.summary: New Icons for the Toolbar

fields.description: I had some extra branches hanging around under the "origin" remote list that I know have been deleted from the server. I right-click on the "origin" remote and choose "Fetch from origin". SourceTree completes the operation, but the bad branches are still shown. Turns out, I need to go to the "Fetch" toolbar button, and enable the "Prune" button to get this functionality. I'd expect this functionality to be the default, or at least available through, the right-click menu on a remote. Until I accidentally tried the "Fetch" toolbar item, I thought SourceTree didn't have this feature, or I was hitting a bug.
fields.summary: Right Click -> Fetch on a remote should prune branches, or give the option to

fields.description:
I have a folder in my project which is mentioned in my .gitignore, but it also has tracked files. When one of these tracked files is modified, it shows up as modified in the working copy and shows me a diff. When I click "stage file" I get an error about the file being ignored, and that I must use -f (but have no way to do this in the UI). I can however click "stage hunk" or "stage selected lines", and this works fine.

I expected that if I can stage hunks and individual lines on a tracked file, I should also be able to stage the whole file.

Also, this may be a separate issue, and one that I don't think is a contributing factor to the above, but I first noticed this when trying to stage modified files in a folder that is ignored in svn:ignore upstream, and I created my local Git repository with git svn clone. The folder doesn't actually appear in any .gitignore file. Where are svn:ignore properties tracked and enforced in my Git repository, if they are not converted to a .gitignore file?

Like I said, I don't think SVN has anything to do with the primary issue here. I tested by adding another folder to my .gitignore, modifying some files in that folder and attempting to stage them to the index.
fields.summary: Can't stage a tracked and modified file when it is in a folder that is ignored.

fields.description: Reported by @x1am on Twitter. For him it's an issue because the repo is large and the fetch takes a long time.
fields.summary: Avoid calling 'git fetch' on pull if we don't need to

fields.description:
As requested by Mike - both he and at least one other user expected the repo-level custom actions to appear on the context menus too. Add them to a sub-menu called 'Global Actions' or similar to keep things tidier, maybe only if there are file/log context menus too.

Also, perhaps show an interactive explanation of which menus the action will appear on based on the parameters specified, as the action is created, to make this clearer. It's in the help which is linked on the dialog, but that's not as immediate.
fields.summary: Add repo-level custom actions to context menus too

fields.description:
Raised here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/36972/path-smart-display

So instead of the ellipsis appearing at the end, make it appear in the middle. This will require a custom subclass of NSTextFieldCell I expect.
fields.summary: When truncating paths, truncate in the middle rather than the end

fields.description: It would be great if you implement a configuration to switch off the submodule support for the whole SourceTree or for particular repositories. The customer i am working for at the moment is developing an application using a submodule that is in development as well. So if i pull SourceTree now allways updates the submodule and i have to switch to it and checkout the working branch again. The reason why i switched from tower to SourceTree was "no submodule support".
fields.summary: make submodule support configurable

fields.description:
Re-purposed this issue from the specific issue below to the more general.

In order to support all the actions possible on the File Status view, more space is needed, which can be partially achieved by dropping the commit details pane. 

In fact, structurally we can drop the entire lower pane and re-embed the file status view verbatim in there.

However the view itself really needs tweaking to be more optimal vertically; ideas include moving the titles of the index / working copy from the top of each section, to down the side (text rotated 90 degrees). Also perhaps make the index area automatically adapt to the vertical size needed, so that it doesn't take up much space most of the time (say max 50% after which it begins to scroll). Minimum size would be one line high to support drag/drop behaviour, or possibly auto-expand on drag (but intuitiveness of the availability of the drop zone could be tricky in that case, so review with prototypes).

Original issue:
When viewing "uncommitted changes" in the "log view", I can "add" untracked files, but I can't "add" a tracked file with changes or "add" a deleted file to the index. I need to change to the working copy view instead or bring up the commit dialogue and "add" changes or deletions to the index from there.

Not a huge deal, but it is an interruption to my workflow as I spend a lot of time in the log view, and it just seems strange. If I can "add" untracked files, it seems logical that I should be able to "add" changes, too. I'm not sure why "add" is greyed out for most changes but works for untracked files, while "remove" and "add/remove" are not greyed out.

The "stage file", "stage hunk" and "stage selected lines" options are also not present from the diff view of modified files in the uncommitted changes view. The only option is to discard.
fields.summary: Enhance log view 'uncommitted changes' view to replicate file status view completely

fields.description: I don't know if this already exists, but I can't find it anyway. So, when you click external diff it shows $LOCAL on the left and $BASE on the right panel. As I work in Xcode all the time I am accustomed to opposite, i.e. left to be $BASE. I am using FileMerge as diff tool in SourceTree preferences. I know I can select "Other" as a diff tool, and set panes with "Arguments" however I like, but in case of FileMerge, if "Other" is selected it always opens new instance of FileMerge and they all stay in the dock...
fields.summary: Option to change left and right panes of external diff

fields.description: I recently updated SourceTree to the latest version.  The application is nearly unusable at this point due to poor performance.  All of the views seem to take several seconds to refresh.
fields.summary: Major performance regressions in latest version

fields.description: I would like to be able to revert files from the Log view as well as it is possible to do from File Status
fields.summary: Revert action for uncommited changes in Log view
Cannot unstage file in a new git repo before the first commit

fields.description:
Trying to commit the file: "hörpå.txt" results in the following error msg:
git rm -q -f -- ho\314\210rpa\314\212.txt 
fatal: pathspec 'ho\314\210rpa\314\212.txt' did not match any files
fields.summary: Can not commit files containing umlauts in file name

fields.description:
If you set a branch to always rebase like this:

git config branch.master.rebase true

then when pulling from the remote the default branch selection is 'rebases' which is incorrect.
fields.summary: Setting the git branch.master.rebase option to true makes Pull sheet select 'rebases' incorrectly

fields.description:
I was going to log as an enhancement, but given how often this has started to affect my workflow, it seems more like a bug.

The Confluence team is heavily using issue branches. This means that there are a lot of branches in the bitbucket.org/confluence repo, easily 50 today. Although we will reclaim many of the branches (after the issue is merged back), I suspect that there will continue to be a reasonable set of branches off master all the time.

When it's time to pull from master, the pull dialog takes 12-15 seconds to finish loading. There is a spinner over the remote branches combo, so I'm assuming that it's fetching them all?

Would it be possible to show only those checked-out with a browse... button when the user explicitly want's to pull from another?
fields.summary: Pull dialog fetches all remote branches

fields.description: View > Refresh or Cmd-R works but since the results are cached make it more obvious.
fields.summary: Add explicit refresh button to Hosted Projects

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

- Create a new hg repository
- Do initial commit & push with e.g. one text file to the default branch
- Go to "Log" view (the middle button in the toolbar)
- Click "Branch"
- Create a new branch - name doesn't matter

Expected results:
- A new branch is created

Current results:
- Application crashes


Notes:
- This can be reproduced with both local or remote hg repositories
- This can be reproduced with both App Store and website-downloadable SourceTree
- I haven't tried this with Git repositories
- Crash logs attached.
fields.summary: Crash in Log view: Current branch view when current branch has zero commits

fields.description:
The additional error checking added in 1.3.1 has a side-effect that 'git log' throws an error when there are no commits and this is reported to the user in a series of annoying dialog boxes.

Find a way to avoid / suppress this. It goes away after the first commit of course.
fields.summary: New error checking gives spurious errors in git log view on newly created repo with no commits

fields.description:
You can already jump to a specific commit in the log by using the 'Jump To' option in the top right.

The trouble is that if you have a very large repository and jumping requires going backwards more than a couple of thousand commits, this can be very slow. That's because in order to populate the graph, SourceTree has to work backwards (you can only follow a DAG that way), and it does so at 200 rows per call. If each call takes about a second, and you need to go back 20,000 commits, you're talking about over 90 seconds before you get to your desired point in the log.

The alternative is to use the Search view, but right now this doesn't search for SHAs (because the assumption was that Jump To achieved that better). Search is much faster for old commits, but lacks the graph context.

See SRCTREE-749 as a related item.
fields.summary: Expand Search to support SHAs in addition to the 'Jump To' option in Log View

fields.description:
I would love to use SourceTree directly from Coda
http://panic.com/coda/

Better yet if i could use SourceTree in the sidebar
fields.summary: Plugin / Integration for Coda

fields.description:
Especially for natural language files, a word diff is often the best way to understand what has changed: it could be simply the addition of a period to a 200 character line. If diffs are simply line-based, one needs to look at a lot of characters to figure out what happened.

Git has a --word-diff flag (try --word-diff=porcelain). I don't use Mercurial, but I would expect it has something similar.
fields.summary: Offer word diff

fields.description: When multiple heads for a given branch exist in a mercurial repository, it would be nice if SourceTree indicated this visually on the log view. At present it is hard to find them, even with Current Branch filtered view.
fields.summary: Show multiple heads in the same branch

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Select one file in the file status view
2. Click the commit button in the menu bar

Result: All pending files are included in the commit

Expected Result: Only the file that was selected is in the commit

This is very annoying and has led to several hg rollbacks to correct accidental commits. If I want to commit all files, I would either select all pending files or leave them all unselected, and then click commit. Both of these methods are currently supported.
fields.summary: Commit Single File if Only One File is Selected in File Status View

fields.description:
I've done this before and not come up with anything, but as reported here there may be an issue when running for several days: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-90

Object Allocations view is the one we want, as discussed here: http://parmanoir.com/Find_your_Garbage_Collection_leaks_with_Instrumentss
fields.summary: Run Instruments again to check for uncollected memory

fields.description:
Vote for your extra keyboard shortcuts here!

From @BigFatGingerCat: 
# Log Selected 
# Blame Selected
fields.summary: Extra keyboard shortcuts

fields.description:
When using https remote URLs, SourceTree offers the ability to remember the password in the keychain.

However the keychain requires that you know the username before you can retrieve the password, and not all URLs include the username (especially Kiln). 

In order to get around this, SourceTree stores a default username for each domain which it uses to try to look up the entry in the keychain if it's not in the URL explicitly. However if this can be ambiguous, e.g. multiple user names on a domain or a mistake in the log in window when first used, this can fail and keep prompting the user for credentials. 

The most reliable way to solve this is to add the username to the URL, as in https://username@host.com/path/to/repo. However this is not necessarily intuitive to a user, and is not the default in Kiln Hosted Projects.

To solve this, it would be better to make the defaulting more effective - taking into account more of the URL in order to clarify ambiguous cases, and overwriting the setting with the last successful use in all cases so it doesn't get out of date.
fields.summary: Better defaulting of username when not specified in https remotes

fields.description:
Raised by @nickstreet on Twitter, who lost some changes because he interpreted the 'Discard File' button in the diff view when selecting a file in the unstaged diff area to mean 'discard only unstaged changes'. In other words, he expected the index to be retained for that file and for the file status in the working copy to returned to the index state.

In fact Discard File resets all changes to the file, including changes in the index. This could be deemed unintuitive because in the context, a user could reasonably expect the 'Discard File' to equate to the same effect as clicking 'Discard Hunk' on all hunks in the diff pane.

'git reset' doesn't actually have a mode which resets the working copy while keeping the index intact, only the opposite (--mixed). To return to the index state you use 'git checkout <files>'. So this is probably what should be done when discarding a file in the unstaged area.
fields.summary: Possible confusion over meaning of 'Discard File' in git diff panel

fields.description:
It would be nice to have a check box for submodule init and submodule update in pull and in clone dialogs.

Does the current version support this somehow? For the time being, I resort to command line for that, which is not very cenvienient.
fields.summary: Submodule init / update

fields.description: Now that Source Tree supports submodules, it would be nice to have them in the bookmarks window as well. More specifically, it would be nice to have one extra line for each submodule, along with the status icons.
fields.summary: Submodules in bookmarks

fields.description: Currently, when the Files view is "Flat", only the Icon, File name and Path are displayed.  It would be highly useful if other column types (perhaps user selectable) were displayed.  i.e. Date Modified, Kind, Size, etc.
fields.summary: Allow for additional column types on files flat view

fields.description: It looks like Sourcetree doesn't handle special characters in Regex pattern well.. If I enter the following: Regex Pattern: #(\d{1,}) Replace With: #$1 and restart Sourcetree the pattern is lost.
fields.summary: Regex pattern lost after restart

fields.description:
If you use the Push dialog and uncheck the 'Track' option, it should stop the local branch tracking the remote, but this doesn't work. It's possible the 'Track' option only actually works when you go from untracked to tracked and not the other way around.

You should also be able to remove the tracking in the sidebar branch context menu, but right now the only options are to track another branch. Should have an extra option in there to track no branch.
fields.summary: Untracking a remote branch in git doesn't seem to work

fields.description:
If you use the Push dialog and uncheck the 'Track' option, it should stop the local branch tracking the remote, but this doesn't work. It's possible the 'Track' option only actually works when you go from untracked to tracked and not the other way around.

You should also be able to remove the tracking in the sidebar branch context menu, but right now the only options are to track another branch. Should have an extra option in there to track no branch.
fields.summary: Untracking a remote branch in git doesn't seem to work

fields.description:
hi, wouldn't it be nice,
to offer the users an alternative bookmark view, where all repository informations are all in one line (see self made photoshop screenshot (i am a programmer not a designer)). that would be useful for having lots of repositories in your bookmarks view. the gui would be less cluttered and more apple like :-) (less is more)

and maybe a search function for the bookmark browser, that es able to search (or filter) the repository name or even the repository description (how cool would that be?!)

and filter the repositories after some common criteria like last changed, name, size (but size doesn't really make a sense),...

think about it :-)
and call it the power user interface enhancement :-)
fields.summary: Improve Bookmark Browser

fields.description:
What if the the numbers against each branch on the left panel is interactive, i.e. it shows that these many changes needs to be pulled or these many to be pushed. 

What if that number when clicked, opens the push/pull dialog for that branch? makes sense?
fields.summary: Make the numbers in Branches sections that indicates number of changes to push/pull interactive.

fields.description:
Mercurial supports a new feature called Phases since version 2.1 [1]. It would be awesome if SourceTree could support this feature, by:

A) Displaying the public/draft/secure phase of each changeset in the log view by e.g. using different background colors
B) Providing user interface to change phase of change sets (e.g. from the contextual menu). 

[1] http://mercurial.selenic.com/wiki/Phases
fields.summary: Add support for Mercurial phases

fields.description:
Cloning a repo with submodules works OK, as does pulling new tracked commits, but if an existing repo has a submodule added and this is pulled into another existing clone, a separate manual step is required.


Might need to check the .gitmodules file after a pull & run submodule init/update?
fields.summary: Pulling a new submodule in git needs to run 'git submodule init/update'

fields.description: Would be very useful to see word-wrapped text in sourcetree. I can see wrapped text if I fire the External Diff app, but seeing it wrapped inside sourcetree would avoid most of the times that I fire the External Diff...
fields.summary: Word wrapping on diffs

fields.description: [Darcs|http://darcs.net/] is a distributed revision control system written in Haskell and particularly popular in that community. Many Haskell users are on OS X, but some have trouble using Darcs on the command line, so I'd be thrilled to have a great tool like SourceTree to point them to.
fields.summary: Darcs support

fields.description:
Related: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-73
SourceTree tends to run as few commands as possible, regardless of the number of files. It's possible that when running for an extremely large lists on low-end machines that this could become a memory issue.

Probably need to come up with a rule of thumb limit on the number of files to be passed in one command, and split the running into multiple tasks.

Other possible solutions include genuinely using the folder level as an argument instead of the full file list, but that has a side-effect of not doing what you'd expect if the list is filtered, by state or otherwise. The user expects all the files in the view to be operated on, not all files which is what a folder parameter would do. So in practice, you can't just use the folder as a proxy in a lot of cases, and it would be dangerous / unintuitive to do so except perhaps in the single case of 'Add' when there is no search filter in force. The splitting approach will deal with all instances without changing behaviour.
fields.summary: Break up very large lists of files into multiple smaller lists for hg/git commands

fields.description:
The last paragraph cuts off.
(See image)
fields.summary: Using Subversion: Guiding Principles Help File is incomplete

fields.description:
In 1.3 the push/pull behaviour from the sidebar was sped up by not checking the remote if there were tracked branches already.

Using the push/pull toolbar buttons though still waits for the remote refresh.

While there are cases when the remote branch information is out of date, in practice it's quite rare. It would be enough to simply grab the remote branches from the locally fetched list and provide a fetch button on the pull/push dialog that users could click if they needed to.
fields.summary: Pull / push - use fetched remote branch info unless explicitly requested

fields.description: The 'Update' tab is supposed to be removed in the App Store version but in 1.3 it's visible and the Custom Actions tab has been removed instead, probably an indexing issue.
fields.summary: App Store version of 1.3 is missing Custom Actions tab in Preferences

fields.description:
For example: 
{PROJECT-265} – http://jira/browse/PROJECT-265
CR{PROJECT-12} – http://jira/browse/PROJECT-12

The reason for this is the fix to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-854 which removed the pre-delimiter requirement, because that prevented multiple JIRA links adjacent to each other.

Need to find a regex construction which separates on the delimiter but doesn't consume it.
fields.summary: If Crucible project code is a superstring of JIRA project code, JIRA link always wins

fields.description:
If a user signs up to Bitbucket using OpenID, they still have to pick a username but can log in using their email address. If they use this email address instead of the username in the Hosted Projects account settings, the URL generated will have 2 '@' characters in it and will be invalid. Since the API login still works with the email, the user won't know why the URL is invalid.

URL escaping the username will probably fix this. Even though ideally the username should be the Bitbucket username and not the email address.
fields.summary: Entering an email address as username in Hosted Projects creates invalid clone URLs

fields.description: This is a feature I really like from GitTower. Often I like to draft the commit message, then start working on something. Just an idea.
fields.summary: Allow draft commit message to be entered from the main screen

fields.description:
h6. SourceTree app downloaded from the Website
I created an Custom Action to launch a script, 
# this doesn't show in the context menu.
# when I press the shortcut key, the custom action is executed; but it ends up failing with an error.

See: http://screencast.com/t/0mfvQbHjdV

h6. SourceTree app downloaded from App Store
# There doesn't seem to be an Custom Actions Preference.
# But there is an TextWrangler Custom Action Context menu, which doesn't seem to work because it picked up my custom action script from before:
http://screencast.com/t/uWKhwBwTSe
fields.summary: Custom Actions don't work at intended.

fields.description: The HEAD indicator was a useful visual clue as to the current state of the code,  especially when you have a lot of branches active. It would be nice to have it turned on again, at least optionally.
fields.summary: Reinstate HEAD indicator

fields.description: Credits.rtf apparently uses a serif'ed font such as Times New Roman. It'd look much better in the About dialog if it used something like Helvetica.
fields.summary: Credits in "About" dialog are unsightly

fields.description:
SourceTree 1.3.1 updated the internal version of Git to 1.7.8 to catch up with the changes they made to submodule clone behaviour.

However, Git 1.7.8 also appears to have changed something in the way it handles SSH_ASKPASS integration, because manual password provision for HTTPS (and probably SSH without a key) now no longer works. Authentication errors will be reported even though the right password is being provided by the askpass hook, which is getting called as before.

Reverting to Git 1.7.7 fixes this immediately. This only affects people using the direct version right now since the version on the App Store is 1.3.0 because of review delays.
fields.summary: Git 1.7.8 change broke SSH_ASKPASS?

fields.description:
If you have a + or - character in your email, Sourcetree doesn't seem to fetch the image from Gravatar:
http://screencast.com/t/5EN9odp6qIq
fields.summary: Gravatars with + or - characters in email aren't fetched

fields.description:
Key linking works only for the first JIRA issue Key in the commit, if you have more that one JIRA issue key the preceding JIRA Keye aren't hyperlinked:
http://screencast.com/t/5eSGnYWU
fields.summary: JIRA issue key linking doesn't work if you have multiple JIRA issues in a commit

fields.description:
Sometimes the annotations and the 'Show' / 'Hide' options on the sidebar disappear, and only re-appear after you widen the sidebar until they appear. It seems to be a view constraint issue, that the size of the sidebar somehow becomes wider than the container and only snaps back after you make the container large enough to hold it again.

I've seen this happen when opening a new window sometimes, and  I've had it reportedly happening after a git pull. So far I haven't managed to track the cause down, all of the sizing constraints seem correctly set.
fields.summary: View constraints issue on sidebar after some operations - annotations disappear

fields.description:
Homebrew will put all packages under '/usr/local/Celler' folder.
Which means if you install Git by homebrew, the installation path will look like:
/usr/local/Celler/git/1.7.8
Then homebrew will create symbol link to '/usr/local/bin' for all the binaries.

In ST system git setting window, navigate to '/usr/local/bin/git' in open file dialog, ST can find the correct path ('/usr/local/Celler/git/1.7.8'), but after upgrade Git, the path will be changed to '/usr/local/Celler/git/1.7.9'.
In this case, ST can't find the new path.
It says "System Git version launch path not accessible".

If I reopen the "Use System Git" dialog, it auto navigate to the new and real path, '/usr/local/Celler/git/1.7.9/git', not symbol link path ('/usr/local/bin/git').
fields.summary: When a symlinked system git is updated (e.g. homebrew), old actual path is referenced & fails

fields.description:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/32119/why-doesn-t-shelve-work-anymore?page=1#32128

The problem sequence is:
# Unshelve some changes, but uncheck the 'Delete after applying'
# Delete the shelved entry
# Try to shelve something else

The problem is that hgattic keeps the entries in .applied and .current which must be manually deleted when you delete the shelved changes, if you don't delete while applying.
fields.summary: Unshelve without deleting, then manually deleting puts hgattic in stuck state

fields.description:
There's a fairly simple way of exporting code without having to manually remove the .git folder and compressing the folder:

git archive --format zip --output /full/path/to/zipfile.zip master

Would be great if this was possible from the SourceTree UI!
fields.summary: Please add support for clean exporting using "git archive"

fields.description:
When you make a window full screen in Lion, the title bar disappears which also means you lose the document name. That's actually the primary way you can identify which repository you're viewing so it can be difficult at first glance to identify repositories in full screen mode.

This is a standard Lion feature and I've had the same problem in other apps. I don't believe there's a way to tell Lion to keep a title bar visible, so it probably means duplicating the identifying information somewhere, perhaps the footer. However, need to avoid wasting too much space on this since it's redundant in non-full screen modes.

(Originally raised on Twitter by @evanlovely)
fields.summary: In full screen mode, title bar disappears so it's hard to know what repo you're viewing

fields.description:
I accidentally set my {{push.default}} setting to {{upstream}} which was invalid. When I looked at my repos on SourceTree, I could see any changes (see screenshot).

It would have been very useful if SourceTree had told me what the problem was. Intellij IDEA was able to give me a very informative message.
fields.summary: Incorrect config settings causes SourceTree to lose everything

fields.description: If you leave the shortcut key field blank, or clear it, the list shows it as Shift-A or occasionally (null). Needs to look better.
fields.summary: Custom actions with no shortcut key appear to have Shift-A

fields.description:
If you try to switch branches - the modal dialog is displayed, regardless of whether are not there are any local changes.

Perhaps we should only display the dialog if there are any local changesets.. 

From customer,
{quote}

When switching branches, I'm always presented with a modal dialog asking me if I really want to switch branches. Of course I do, I just told the app to switch branches. Why is the software getting in my way to ask me to confirm the thing I just told it to do, which is harmless and easy to undo?

This is a poor use of a modal dialog, especially when I'm trying to get work done. It seriously interrupts my workflow.
{quote}
fields.summary: Don't display modal dialog when switching branches

fields.description: IN log view I have a number (1 or more) of changesets that are not yet pushed.  However, there is no indication in my tree of which changesets these are.  Sourcetree should highlight them in some way (asterisk? italic? background colour???).
fields.summary: In log view show which changesets are not pushed.

fields.description:
Accessibility issue - they can be difficult to distinguish for colourblind users. The +/- margin markers mean it's still possible but would be better to allow customisation.

Originally raised here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/31151/customize-colors-in-diff-view-in-sourcetree?page=1#31258
fields.summary: Allow diff panel colours to be customised

fields.description:
Requested by @NeoNacho on Twitter.

Justification: using different diff tools per project and potentially per file type. 

External Diff would possibly be a drop-down push-button style with a default which is remembered per project based on the last one used.

Keyboard shortcuts would have to still use the current default.

Mercurial and git can have multiple external diff tools configured so that shouldn't be a problem.
fields.summary: Support multiple diff tools

fields.description: If you change the commit of a subrepository, it should show up as an uncommitted change in the file status like it does in git. However this doesn't seem to be working.
fields.summary: Mercurial subrepo commit change doesn't show up as uncommitted

fields.description:
I would like to request that you add support for Bazaar (bzr) along with the other VCS's. I am using this for my current project and I think I am going to be encountering it regularly in the future. It would be nice to have a single GUI VCS client.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Support for Bazaar

fields.description:
Requested by @chrisyipw on Twitter.

The benefit of this would be if the section is collapsed, to know that there's something to display. This is especially useful in Lion since the 'disclosure triangle' is no longer displayed on the left of the top-level items, like it was in Snow Leopard and previously, so you can't tell if there's something to see without clicking 'Show'.
fields.summary: Display the number of branches/tags/remotes/submodules in sidebar

fields.description:
Originally raised https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-65

Entering a revision works, selecting a branch does not. It should be adding the '-b branch' option.
fields.summary: Mercurial push branch selection (Advanced) is not working

fields.description: I would find the ability to sort bookmarks both at the top level and within groups alphabetically very helpful. I currently have 44 git repositories bookmarked in SourceTree and I'm trying to avoid manually sorting.  The height of each bookmark row makes it difficult to get a high level overview of all my bookmarks at one time.
fields.summary: Alphabetical sort ordering of bookmarks

fields.description:
Twitter user @chrisyipw reported that a submodule they'd cloned via Git 1.7.8 wasn't showing up in SourceTree until they switched to their system Git, and SourceTree couldn't open it.

Further information has been that there is no '.git' folder inside the submodule, only a '.git' *file* which includes a 'git-dir' statement, which it seems refers to somewhere else.

Git 1.7.8 only just became available on OS X as an official build and I haven't tried it yet. I'm wondering if they've completely changed the way that submodules are referenced, moving the .git repo itself into another location. See this comment in the release notes:


{quote}
When populating a new submodule directory with "git submodule init",
   the $GIT_DIR metainformation directory for submodules is created inside
   $GIT_DIR/modules/<name>/ directory of the superproject and referenced
   via the gitfile mechanism. This is to make it possible to switch
   between commits in the superproject that has and does not have the
   submodule in the tree without re-cloning.
{quote}

Checking this out. If this is the case, this is a major PITA and a fairly substantial breaking change.
fields.summary: Cope with Git 1.7.8 submodule referencing changes

fields.description:
I'd appreciate a 'Discard all' button in the diff view when several files are selected
Useful for example when permissions of files were changed
fields.summary: Discard all button

fields.description: SourceTree seems to have no means to create a multi-head merge in git ("octopus" merge). It would be great if the merge GUI dialogs allowed for this possibility.
fields.summary: Allow Git Octopus merges

fields.description: Git allows multiple branches to be merged in at once ("octopus" merge), and if a repository has a history including an octopus merge, only the first two heads are shown merged in the tree view, making all the other heads look like dangling leaf nodes. This is only visual; the branches are merged, but it leads to some confusion among developers who don't look to deeply.
fields.summary: Git Octopus merges don't include all heads

fields.description: After a merge commit, the node in the tree view that indicates the uncommitted changes has parent lines drawn to the merge commit, AND the head of the branch that was merged into the commit prior (see attachment: see that the uncommitted node attaches to the head of the green (leftmost) branch, and the head of the purple (second from left) branch that was merged with the green branch the last commit). After committing, the new commit only has one parent (the merge commit), which is correct. It's only the view when it's not committed yet that's inaccurate; it should only point to the head of the currently-active branch.
fields.summary: Uncommitted changes after a merge appear to have two parents

fields.description: Requested by @k0raktor on Twitter, this is to help keep messages readable in terminals. Only makes sense when Preferences are set to use a fixed width font in the commit window of course.
fields.summary: Display user-definable column limit in commit window when fixed width font in use

fields.description:
Currently we use git flow (see https://github.com/nvie/gitflow or http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/).

Unfortunately currently we have to use the command line for this purpose.

Since git flow is really a great tool, support in source tree would be really cool.
fields.summary: git flow support would be cool
Merge: possibility to select a branch to merge in instead of a commit

fields.description:
Since I have to switch between branches quite frequently (by double-clicking the branch), I would like to disable the confirmation message.

A checkbox "don't show this message again" ore something like this would be cool.
fields.summary: Allow user to turn off confirmation message when switching to a different branch

fields.description:
When looking at a list of diffs, in any of the three viewing modes, the spacebar brings up the Mac preview of the file.  I'd like to suggest that it would be more helpful and intuitive to use space and shift-space for scrolling the diffs.  This would be a mode of interaction very much like Apple Mail.  (Perhaps a modifier could be added for preview.)

In any case I think there should be some way to "flip through" all of the diffs using the keyboard.  If there is, I haven't been able to discover it, and again I think the spacebar most fits my expectation.

If this is done, I think the spacebar should also jump to the next file to diff after the file is scrolled to the bottom.
fields.summary: Repurpose spacebar to scroll diffs

fields.description:
When cloning, take the last path component entry and default the other fields from it. Minus any '.git' suffix if present.

http://cl.ly/2P273N0x2w1o071F3k44
fields.summary: Default project folder and bookmark name from last path component

fields.description: Requested by Mike
fields.summary: Add "Don't tell me again" option to warning box when committing with no message

fields.description:
In my repository, I've got a directory which name starts with a dash: -test in my setup.

When handling these files through SourceTree (eg. adding them for commit) SourceTree fails.

From the "Full Output" window:
{noformat}
git add -test/file

error: unknown switch 't'
...
{noformat}
fields.summary: handling files or paths starting with dash (-) fails

fields.description:
SourceTree uses existence of an .git/svn directory to detect if git project is using the git svn extension. That is a problem because any git svn command creates this directory even though the git project has nothing to do with subversion.

Because SourceTree itself then uses git svn it may keep reappearing even though it is deleted.
fields.summary: SourceTree uses existence of svn directory to detect if git project is using the git svn extension

fields.description: The Chinese characters show up as UTF-8 encoded characters.
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't display Chinese characters

fields.description: What do you think about ability to untrack some files from repo? Currently, AFAIK, I can only remove files. But sometimes I need to «forget» files without deletion. For this I usually go to command line (or to MacHG). I think it's not very hard to implement?
fields.summary: Ability to untrack files in repo
Provide a faster way to search for all files in file status view
Bitbucket is not linked in the documentation.

fields.description:
There are multiple mistakes in french translation, I'm not going to make a snapshot for every mistake though. 
So if you could just provide me with the generated *.strings files so I could highlight and correct mistakes, that would be nice.

Monteer Branches Distantes => Afficher les branches distantes
Cacher Branches Distante => Cacher les branches distantes

Anyway, you made an amazing app here guys!
fields.summary: French translation mistakes

fields.description:
It would be GREAT if you could add the following improvements to search (unless I missed them somehow):

1. search by file path similar to gitx (i.e. show me all commits where this file path expression was involved)

2. option to use regular expressions in search terms (again, like gitx)

3. search by commit hash (like gitx)


For those types of searchs I still have to go back to the command line or gitx, and it'd be nice to be able to use SourceTree for that as well.  Disclaimer: my only experience with SoruceTree has been using it with git, so I don't know if they would be applicable for Hg or SVN as well.
fields.summary: Enhance search (similar to what gitx offers)

fields.description: Cannot close preferences window when "Allow SourceTree to modify your global Mercurial and Git configuration files" checkbox is selected.  I have read and write permission on my gitconfig file and I have the name and email address fields filled out.
fields.summary: Cannot close preferences window

fields.description: unable to set merge with no fast forward.  Is this option available?  Wasn't able to find much documentation on the external diff/merge command and arguments.
fields.summary: Add Git Preferences option for --no-ff by default
